Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
As a healthcare quality leader, I’ve had the privilege and challenge of spearheading digital health transformation and witnessing up close the opportunities for improvement. I sincerely applaud CMS for initiating this RFI regarding the health technology ecosystem. I submit these reflections to help guide CMS and ONC toward a future where digital tools are truly care-enabling.
1)	To truly advance quality and safety in healthcare, we must move beyond static, retrospective measures and instead incorporate the lived experiences of patients as active contributors to improvement. Current tools like HCAHPS, while valuable, offer a limited and often delayed view of care experiences, missing key dimensions such as emotional safety, real-time responsiveness, and other nuances of care that are necessary to really improve care. Patients are more than survey respondents - they are experts in how care feels and functions across settings. CMS should support infrastructure that enables continuous, bidirectional feedback loops - integrating patient stories, PROMs (Patient-Reported Outcome Measures), PREMs (Patient-Reported Experience Measures), and digital feedback channels into the core of quality measurement. Embedding patient voice will not only improve outcomes for all Americans, it will rebuild trust in care.

Policy recommendation:

•	Develop a mechanism to collect beneficiaries experiences and outcomes through multiple channels (online, phone/text, etc).  Such a mechanism is vital to understanding/addressing care gaps and identifying brights spots (and learning why they are bright spots).  Such a tool could inform initiatives across HHS.

2)	Patients deserve real control and understanding of their health data, as well as a prominent voice that shapes healthcare quality. Currently, patients often struggle to navigate multiple portals just to access labs or visit summaries. A truly person-centered ecosystem should provide access to the full spectrum of data that influences health, including prior authorization status, social needs, and benefits information. Expansion of Blue Button to include these elements could enable a new generation of apps that help people manage their care - not just when they’re sick, but every day. Furthermore, 
Policy recommendations:
•	Expand Blue Button application programming interfaces (APIs) to include Medicare Advantage encounter data, prior authorization status, and community referrals. 
•	Support Bulk FHIR export for patients switching providers or apps, ensuring portability.

3)	For providers, technology should reduce friction -not introduce more. Promising digital tools often cannot have the impact they should due to barriers in implementation specific to electronic health records. CMS could support better alignment by requiring modular, standards-based APIs, promoting ingestion of community and wearable data, and ensuring clinical utility is prioritized in certification criteria.
Policy recommendations:
•	Mandate EHRs support modular, plug-and-play APIs for external tools, including SMART-on-FHIR launch contexts
•	Require ingestion and export of patient-generated health data from wearables, home devices, and community sources via FHIR Device and Observation resources.
•	Include support for FHIR Document Reference and Optical Character Recognition of scanned legacy files to reduce paper-based silos.
•	Incentivize clinical decision support that integrate real-time data into provider workflows (e.g., maternal early warning systems, risk flags).

4)	Many brilliant startups wither due to opaque hospital integration costs or prohibitive certification requirements. CMS has an opportunity to change this. A national open marketplace for certified digital health tools - paired with technical assistance for early-stage developers - would be a meaningful step toward democratizing access to innovation. Additionally, monitoring and publishing common interoperability “pain points” would bring needed transparency to the developer experience and promote trust across the ecosystem.
Policy recommendations:
•	Create a CMS-led open marketplace of certified digital tools with transparency around integration capabilities and TEFCA compliance.
•	Establish a developer technical assistance program for early-stage or under-resourced vendors serving high-need populations.
•	Mandate vendor reporting of integration fees and timelines as a condition of certification.
•	Publicly track and publish patterns of interoperability blocking, similar to the HHS Transparency in Coverage rule’s approach.

As someone inspired by MAHA’s mission to elevate innovation that promotes health and transparency, I would be honored to support this work more directly. The future of care should be personal, proactive, and digitally fluent - and I would be delighted to contribute to shaping that future.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
I am a 30 year experienced product innovator with 18 patents and a career launching products for Amazon Web Services, Intel, Health Hero Network, Age Wave, and Electronic Caregiver. I lead the AgeTech Group for the Forbes Technology Council. I also serve as a Mentor to the National Institute of Health (NIH) Start-Up Challenge. Given the depth and breadth of my experience, coupled with the gravity of the chronic illness endemic and clinical provider shortage in the country, I strongly encourage the reviewers and Secretary to scale existing, proven AI-technology solutions and focus new innovation efforts into greenfield applications. Electronic Caregiver's Addison Care solution is a generative AI-powered conversational virtual caregiver which transforms the patient engagement and care adherence paradigm. 

This culturally-appropriate solution enables patients to select the race, gender, language, age, attire, holidays, and attire for their 24/7/365 caregiver - resulting in unmatched utilization and engagement. As a result, the significant health consequences of social isolation, loneliness, and depression are mitigated. Given the relationship developed, research has shown that the patients are more compliant and more honest in completing care surveys (Katz ADL Index, Johns Hopkins Falls Risk Assessment, SF12, etc.), measuring vitals, managing medications, and sharing status with human care coaches. As a result, clinical professionals receive timely, accurate, and actionable intelligence on the health and wellness of patients - improving health outcomes and optimizing resource utilization. 

The impact has been shown to be transformational: elimination of Type 2 diabetes, 47% reduction in readmissions for a rural hospital system, 70% expansion of bed capacity via hospital-at-home programs, and remote patient monitoring provided at 1/50th of the cost of hospital-based care. 

The ECG platform was specifically built as an open platform designed for integration with other healthcare technology companies, device companies, electronic health records (EHRs), pharmaceutical management platforms, revenue cycle management solutions, and service providers to address social determinants of health (SDoH). Moreover, built leveraging natural language processing, speech-to-text, and translation capabilities from AWS and Google, patients can engage with the platform in their native language. Simultaneous translation enables timely cross-language communications amongst all participants in the care circle, leading to better care and higher quality care. 

AI-driven care will play a central role to provide world-class care to all Americans. Solutions such as Addison Care - deployed at scale - will knock down barriers to care, expand access to care, and enable clinical professionals to have unforeseen insights into the health and wellness of patients in all settings. An open platform which brings together best-in-class capabilities into a unified and engaging interface for patients, clinicians, and non-clinical caregivers would be a fantastic complement to the capabilities and reach of the clinical EHRs which have developed over the past three decades. Now is the time for the community-based equivalent. I strongly encourage a deep review, analysis, and demo of ECG's existing products, services, integrations, and roadmap.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
This comment proposes that CMS develop and implement a patient-facing, AI-powered navigation assistant assigned to Medicare beneficiaries at enrollment. The assistant would integrate plan, provider, and pharmacy data using existing interoperability standards (FHIR, HL7, APIs) and follow beneficiaries across care settings and plan years.

The recommendation addresses persistent gaps in care continuity, administrative burden, and digital access, particularly among older adults. It is grounded in over two decades of experience supporting provider workflows, patient navigation, and technology adoption within clinical settings.

The attached document outlines the proposed solution in detail, supported by current data on provider shortages, clinician burnout, and patient acceptance of AI in healthcare.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Recorded Health Inc. is a U.S.-based software company committed to developing platform-based solutions that empower patients, healthcare providers, and payers to consolidate, integrate, analyze, and collaborate around patient-level clinical, operational, and financial data. Our solutions leverage modern data representation architectures and AI-powered analytics to drive better, faster, and smarter decision-making. Data privacy, security, and regulatory compliance are foundational to our work. At our core, we believe that operationalizing data in a patient-centered, secure, and scalable manner is essential for meaningful change in healthcare delivery.

The U.S. healthcare system is in urgent need of a shift toward a model that prioritizes patient sovereignty, data control, and transparent data representation—ultimately flipping the existing power dynamic. We are honored to work toward these goals and to help catalyze a reimagined healthcare future. Recorded Health, along with our solution partners, is pleased to provide our perspectives to inform CMS and ASTP/ONC in their efforts to assess, adopt, and deploy patient-empowerment technologies. We view this initiative as mission critical—a necessary catalyst for a true U.S. healthcare reformation.

Our response to this RFI is based on experience gathered over decades of hands-on patient care, the development of technologies that measurably improve clinical, operational, and financial outcomes, and translational research that bridges innovation and real-world application. We hope our insights and recommendations contribute meaningfully to CMS and ASTP/ONC’s mission to deliver ever-better, ever-improving health and wellbeing to the individuals and communities they serve.

Visit Recorded Health Inc, at www.recordedhealth.com for more information.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Dear Deputy Administrator Carlton:

RE: Request for Information: Health Technology Ecosystem (CMS–0042–NC)

On behalf of WyDus, LLC, thank you for the opportunity to comment on the Request for Information titled Health Technology Ecosystem issued by the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS), the Assistant Secretary for Technology Policy (ASTP), and the Office of the National Coordinator for Health Information Technology (ONC).

WyDus, LLC is a consulting firm supporting digital health, diagnostic, and medtech innovators navigating reimbursement and market access in the U.S. healthcare system. These comments also reflect my personal perspective as a cancer survivor who has directly experienced the gaps in data access and care coordination highlighted by this RFI.

Summary of Recommendations

Improve Access to Second Opinions in Cancer Care
Launch a CMS demonstration program to support the development of a unified digital platform that enables patients to easily obtain second opinions. To encourage provider participation, the program should include reimbursement for digital pathology services and multidisciplinary tumor board reviews. The demonstration should assess the impact on diagnostic accuracy, treatment planning, rural access, and patient outcomes.

Increase Reimbursement Predictability for Digital Health Tools
•	Establish an NTAP-equivalent program under the OPPS to support digital tools not currently eligible for TPT or new technology APCs.
•	Create a structured and timely payment pathway for new digital health services delivered in physician office settings.
•	Extend the NTAP period for digital health technologies to allow sufficient time for evidence development and support broader market adoption.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment: Can HHS provide clarification on whether submitting electronic prior authorizations (or e-prescribing) alone trigger HIPAA covered entity status for a medical practice?  In other words, if a physician never submits electronic claims, but uses an insurance company's prior authorization portal to help a patient obtain coverage for a prescription or for a diagnostic test like an MRI, is that physician a HIPAA covered entity due to submitting an electronic prior authorization electronically.  What about submitting electronic prescriptions?  Would that activity trigger HIPAA covered entity status for a physician who is trying to maintain their "country doctor exemption" to HIPAA regulations.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
RE: CMS-0042-NC

As an independent health advocate, I assist families in navigating the healthcare system and ensuring their health needs are met wherever they go (school, work, home, community, etc.). Quite often the first step with a new client involves gathering medical records and creating a workable medical history. This can take weeks to months depending on the health provider/health system the patient utilizes. 

While most providers have electronic records, those electronic records do not always come with easy access for the patient or their caregiver. Many outpatient health providers do not connect their electronic records systems to larger hospital systems, forcing patients and caregivers to request information from multiple sources. Even more importantly, these records are incomplete, often not including lab results, surgical reports, or other detailed testing/treatment. Depending on the health provider/system and how their electronic records system is setup, the patient and caregiver might only have access to partial records, forcing them to request paper records in writing, incurring costs, and waiting for those to be mailed and received. Considering specialized services like labs and radiology centers, these results are often not electronically available to a patient at all.

There are few health-related applications that allow a patient or caregiver to connect their medical record portals, curate notes/history, or share that information with others. Primary Record is the best application our agency has used and highly recommends it to each client. However, their platform is limited by the health providers/systems regulations and how they share patient records. Because each state also has different guidelines, patients who see providers across state lines, or who move, face significant difficulties in connecting past medical history to current and sharing that information with new providers.

There is also a significant gap in regulations for protected classes of patients, such as minors age 12-17. Their access to electronic records is limited and largely dependent on health provider/system rules (or lack thereof). In many instances, parents/caregivers are cut off from having electronic access to records, but there is no mechanism to allow the minor patients electronic access. Families are forced to request records in person, along with the minor patient. Thus when a minor patient becomes a legal adult, there are no electronic records or access to pass along from the parent/caregiver to patient. The patient must start their medical record keeping at ground zero.

A single point of access for patients and caregivers is essential as the healthcare system becomes increasingly challenging to navigate. As we live in times where technology can be helpful or hindering, healthcare as a system must make great strides to ensure every patient and caregiver can access their full medical records electronically, with ease.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
RE:  ATA Action Response to Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Request for Information Information Health Technology Ecosystem (CMS-0042-NC)

Dear Administrator Oz,

On behalf of ATA Action, we are pleased to offer the below comments in response to the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid (“CMS” or the “Agency”) request for information with the goal of removing unnecessary barriers to digital health access and promoting health care innovation.

ATA Action, the American Telemedicine Association’s affiliated trade association, is focused on ensuring all individuals have permanent access to digital health products and services across the care continuum. ATA Action supports the enactment of state and federal digital health coverage and appropriate payment policies to secure digital health access for all Americans, including those in rural and underserved communities. ATA Action recognizes that digital health products and services have the potential to truly transform the health care delivery system – by improving patient outcomes, enhancing safety and effectiveness of care, addressing health disparities, and reducing costs – if only allowed to flourish. 

We are excited to share with you that ATA Action acquired the Digital Therapeutics Alliance (DTA) on March 31, 2025. The DTA was the leading international nonprofit trade organization focused on expanding access to digital therapeutics. Through this acquisition, ATA Action expanded its advocacy efforts to support digital health tools such as digital therapeutics, digital diagnostics, remote monitoring devices, and artificial intelligence by forming the Advancing Digital Health Coalition.

As a preliminary matter, we recognize the importance of the Agency’s deregulation efforts and encourage the removal of unnecessary digital health barriers while prioritizing regulations and guidance that encourage innovation.  We also thank the Agency for its ongoing efforts to increase beneficiary access to effective digital capabilities.  As further discussed below, we believe that a combination of deregulation and targeted guidance is necessary to promote health care innovation and digital health adoption.

Please find the entire comment in the "Attach Files" Section.

Kind regards,
Kyle Zebley 
Executive Director
ATA Action

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
The American Pharmacists Association (APhA) appreciates the opportunity to provide comments to CMS, the Assistant Secretary for Technology Policy/Office of the National Coordinator for Health Information Technology (ASTP/ONC), and the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) regarding its request for information, “Health Technology Ecosystem.” APhA shares HHS’s desire to increase data availability to all of a patient's health care providers to achieve better patient health outcomes. As such, APhA encourages CMS, ASTP/ONC, and HHS to consider the vital role that pharmacists have in a patient’s overall health, work towards promoting the interoperability of electronic health information (EHI) with pharmacies and pharmacists, and recognize pharmacists as health care providers to prevent information-blocking.. 

APhA is the largest association of pharmacists in the United States, advancing the entire pharmacy profession. APhA represents pharmacists, scientists, student pharmacists, and pharmacy technicians in all practice settings, including but not limited to community pharmacies, hospitals, long-term care facilities, specialty pharmacies, community health centers, physician offices, ambulatory clinics, managed care organizations, hospice settings, and government facilities. Our members strive to improve medication use, advance patient care, and enhance public health.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
I respectfully submit this response to CMS drawing upon 36 years of continuous work dedicated to innovating and improving the value, efficiency, and equity of healthcare delivery in the United States. My career has been grounded in advancing health system transformation by aligning technology, policy, and care delivery to better serve patients and care teams alike.

I currently serve on the Board of Directors of the American Academy of Home Care Medicine (AAHCM), where I support efforts to expand home-based primary care and improve outcomes for high-need populations. I am also an Industry Advisor to HL7, helping shape interoperability standards that support real-time, patient-centered care across the continuum. As a Strategic Advisor to the Association for Value-Based Cancer Care (AVBCC), I work to accelerate specialty care transformation aligned with CMS's goals for interoperability, equity, and outcomes.

Previously, I served as a Board Member of the Workgroup for Electronic Data Interchange (WEDI), and was honored with the Louis Sullivan WEDI Award for National Leadership, recognizing my longstanding contributions to health information exchange and system modernization. Additionally, I have served as a strategic advisor to the National Committee for Quality Assurance (NCQA) in advancing digital quality measurement and value-based care frameworks.

My comments reflect both strategic experience and hands-on collaboration with a wide range of stakeholders—from government agencies and standards bodies to payers, providers, and technology innovators—working toward the same shared mission: a healthcare system that delivers better outcomes, lower costs, and a more equitable experience for all.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Thank you for the opportunity to respond to the Health Technology Ecosystem CMS-0042-NC under RFI – RIN 0938-AV68, which shows the commitment of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) to improve the healthcare system. In the attached file, Claritev is providing direct responses to several questions posed in this RFI and is also offering our perspective on multiple overarching themes and considerations that, if applied across CMS, can:  
•	Enhance the existing ecosystem to optimize the patient healthcare journey in conjunction with stakeholders, patients and caregivers 
•	Empower beneficiaries with better access to tools, personalized care navigation and information about treatments and cost so that beneficiaries can make informed, value-driven care decisions  
•	Reduce systemic barriers to care by expanding access in underserved populations and closing provider gaps in rural areas  
•	Utilize proven and emerging AI-based solutions to improve patient and caregiver experiences by leveraging data across multiple platforms to build a patient-centric experience 
•	Incentivize providers to optimize care with real-time, accurate and actionable data 
•	Aggressively modernize tools to quickly identify and mitigate fraud, waste and abuse through AI. 
We look forward to further discussions on all of Claritev’s recommendations and perspectives.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment: On behalf of the American Association of Orthopaedic Executives (AAOE), representing more than 1,500 orthopaedic practice leaders nationwide, we appreciate the opportunity to respond to the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services' Request for Information on the Health Technology Ecosystem. As the federal government continues to shape a digital-first, patient-centric healthcare system, AAOE is committed to ensuring that the perspectives of orthopaedic practices—especially those operating in diverse and often resource-constrained settings—are meaningfully incorporated into future policy development. Our comments reflect the unique challenges and opportunities our members face in integrating digital tools, achieving interoperability, and participating in value-based care models.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
The healthcare landscape is more complex than ever due to evolving regulations, staffing shortages, and unpredictable supply chain disruptions. In addition, clinicians are tasked with working in fast-paced environments while navigating outdated systems.

Today, various systems that clinicians use are often disconnected. These include electronic health records, laboratory and imaging systems, pharmacy and medication systems, admission, billing, and patient discharge platforms.

When providers are focused on screens instead of patients, the risk of error rises, leading to missed information, medication mistakes, and unnecessary or repeated tests. This leads to slower care, lower satisfaction, and compromised patient trust.

To improve outcomes, healthcare leaders must evolve past outdated systems and opt for solutions that allow for open interoperability. Interoperability refers to the seamless exchange and use of health data within hospital and healthcare systems, applications, and devices.

Weak points in medication management systems compromise patient safety. It is critical that clinicians have access to the right information at the right time to create proper treatment plans and deliver the highest level of care. Intelligent medication management software that connects and contextualizes information from different systems is a critical at the point of care. 

A common problem that we hear from pharmacists is that they don’t have a single source of truth across systems. When this happens, they ask themselves, “Which information can I trust? The data that lives in the EHR, or the different data that lives within the medication administration record?” And sometimes, neither of those coincide with the information in the billing system, causing provider and patient frustration. 

The goal of interoperability is to seamlessly allow the data living throughout these siloed systems to unite, reducing administrative burden, and creating smoother workflows. As a result, patients can rest assured that they are receiving quality care they deserve, being billed correctly for services, and that the information they receive prior, during, and after care can be verified quickly.

Interoperability isn’t just a technology challenge for clinicians—it’s a regulatory and public health imperative. 

On a broader scale, interoperability is a current requirement in our healthcare supply chain through the Drug Supply Chain Security Act (DSCSA). While it is critical for pharmacists and clinicians to have systems in place that provide data integrity at the point of care, DSCSA mandates additional visibility. Under these enhanced regulations, drug manufacturers, wholesalers, distributors, and dispensers must securely and electronically exchange transaction information at the unit level. These standards aim to keep our healthcare supply chain safe by preventing illegitimate prescription drugs from entering the market and being administered to patients.

Our mission at Intelliguard is to create a world where an intelligent information ecosystem empowers healthcare providers to focus on patient-centered care. We partner with hospitals across the nation to transform physical activity into actionable data. The once disconnected data becomes structured, searchable, and available in real-time. This is made possible with Mira Intelligence, a comprehensive intelligent dashboard that exists within our AI-powered Mira Ecosystem. Additionally, Mira Intelligence provides cross-departmental alignment by bridging communication gaps in medication workflows with tailored dashboards for pharmacy directors, supply chain managers, compliance officers, clinical staff, and C-suite executives.

Technological advancements are driving better outcomes and healthier lives for patients. The industry is shifting beyond the outdated “one size fits all” mindset when it comes to treating patients. When clinicians have what they need at their fingertips, they can create customized treatment plans that take genetic makeup, lifestyle, and environmental factors into consideration.

An open, interoperable system isn’t the solution in itself; it is the result of adopting an intelligent, AI-powered medication management solution that transforms fragmented data into actionable insights. Medication management systems that enable interoperability, like the Mira Ecosystem, create safer environments for patients and empower providers by improving clinical processes, capabilities, and most importantly—patient care.

CMS has an opportunity to accelerate the adoption of interoperable digital healthcare infrastructure. Based on industry regulations and transformation that is underway, we urge CMS to incentivize the adoption of interoperable solutions and intelligent medication management systems across healthcare settings to alleviate provider burnout and staffing shortages, reduce administrative burden, enhance efficiency, and improve patient outcomes.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Why do Mobile Medical services -- Fire services, Emergency Medical Services, Non-Emergency Medical / Interfacility Transport services, Critical Care services (both ground and air), and Community Paramedicine services -- not use the tools that are already available to them, despite obvious utility?  Why build something new and potentially disconnected? 

Leveraging existing data interoperability resources would afford the Mobile Medical agencies and their hospital partners discrete data interoperability (for improved care and operations, potentially including an elimination of paper handoffs at the emergency department, and reduced ambulance offload times); as well as visibility into all manner of medical complexities, from disabilities that are electricity dependent, to rare conditions such as hemophilia that (if known) can alter emergency response, to the presence of end-of-life medical orders (e.g., POLST forms), and even the persistent risk of post-discharge death following treatment of patients for substance use disorders in the emergency department.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
As founder of GenHealth.ai https://genhealth.ai and 1upHealth. Over the past decade I have helped nearly 70 health plans stand up CMS-mandated FHIR APIs, connected to 1000s of provider systems, and now deliver AI-driven analytics on 140 million patient records. That experience gives me a unique lens into the HIT regulations, standards, technology across the government, patients, clinicians, and payers.

Despite progress with Patient Access APIs, adoption remains low due to limited patient incentives. While health plans and providers are motivated to use this data to improve outcomes and reduce costs, two key issues prevent API standards from replacing traditional connectivity methods to improve outcomes: 

1. The full patient record is not sent via FHIR
2. Ease of access to data is still blocked by gatekeepers at EHRs and other platforms

1) The record that travels through FHIR is incomplete. USCDI and proposed Prior Auth standards like Da Vinci are insufficient to stand in for direct EHR access, FAX transmissions, and PDF exports. They cannot power prior-authorization automation, HEDIS gap closure, or risk-adjustment analytics. Much of the evidence behind those workflows—physician narratives, imaging summaries, operative reports—remains locked in PDFs or images. Worse, real-world implementations vary so widely that the same data element appear in different resources or extensions.

2) Equally damaging is the friction in turning on data access. A hospital that wishes to connect a third-party population level app still faces months of back-and-forth between the EHR and the vendor before credentials are issued. For example we have first hand experience with multiple leading EHRs that had health IT companies on ice for up to 9 months before granting access to the EHR's FHIR apis even after the health systems wanted to provide access.

Furthermore, many of these standards and rules were envisioned nearly a decade ago, well before we imagined the generative AI tech that is now commoditized. We now have an opportunity to re-think the standards and regs with an AI forward mindset that positions healthcare IT for 5 years out when many of these regulations will be in full play. 


PROPOSAL 1: MOVE THE ENTIRE RECORD, NOT JUST THE DISCRETE SLICE

AI is now adept at processing unstructured data. Instead of creating administrative burden by structuring data into specific FHIR resources, we can send complete unstructured data through FHIR APIs via DocumentReference and Binary resources. For example, for prior auth requests, payers should receive full PDFs showing therapy history and imaging. AI Vision-Language models can now efficiently process these documents - from checking for required signatures to analyzing complex clinical criteria. Traditional approaches like CQL for quality measures or prior auth decision trees are creating unnecessary complexity when LLMs can handle these tasks more accessibly and at lower cost. Questions requiring nuanced clinical understanding (like "Could the beneficiary not be fit with a prefabricated AFO?") are better suited for AI analysis of complete records rather than structured queries. At GenHealth, we've proven this approach works - processing thousands of prior auths daily using AI with 95% accuracy and 75% faster processing times, already meeting 2026 turnaround requirements. 

Ultimately supporting these use cases on the interoperability and authorization rails already established with FHIR will lead to better patient outcomes at lower costs.


PROPOSAL 2: MAKE SMART ON FHIR TRULY SELF-SERVICE

Technical capability is meaningless if turning it on stays painful. I urge CMS and ONC to mandate that any certified health-IT platform allow an authorized administrator—at a provider or payer—to enable a third-party app for both SMART on FHIR "Launch" context and Bulk Data in ten clicks or fewer. A typical flow should look like the developer consoles used by Google or Stripe:

1. Enter app name and redirect URI.
2. Choose environment (test or production).
3. Tick required scopes—e.g.,  patient, bulk, launch.
4. Confirm terms, pick patient population, and click "Generate keys."

The portal returns client ID and secret instantly, with no vendor ticket and no new servers or IT implementation required by the covered entity's IT team. Users of the data can leverage AI and are motivated enough to make the returned API data useful. 


THE UPSIDE

Adopting these two changes creates a win-win-win dynamic: patients gain faster approvals and better care insights through AI analysis, providers and payers reduce administrative burden to focus on clinical work, and government achieves simpler oversight with improved compliance rates and faster timelines.

I appreciate HHS leadership to date and recommend the agency focus rules on data completeness and time to access - two levers that can help make interoperability truly a problem of the past.

Ricky Sahu

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Note the RFI Summary lead-in, “Effective and responsible adoption of technology can empower patients to make better decisions for their health and well-being”. We believe this Administration is uniquely qualified to turn the tables on an HIT infrastructure currently subservient to everything big: big government and big institutions, including big providers, big health plans, big vendors, big pharma...

“Patient-centric” and “patient empowerment” are contending buzzwords but are entirely peripheral considerations to many of the most highly-promoted HIT infrastructure “solutions”. Individual clinicians have also been brushed aside, with little attention to their pleas for focus on usability, efficacy and burden reduction. Deserving they are, yet bearing little recognition, ever relegated to the role of small cogs in a big wheel.

Although we didn’t have time to fully address every RFI question we worked to examine muddles and mania in current HIT infrastructure and to offer worthy suggestions in our quest for “effective and responsible adoption of technology [to] empower patients”.

See full set of RFI responses included in attached .pdf file.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
It is good that CMA, ASTP/ONC and HHS are seeking input about Health Technology from each of the involved parties.

I am an individual working for a payer but commenting as an individual and not on behalf of my organization.

PA-1: For TEFCA, the common agreement can change over time and requires that whatever it specifies must be done. This does not allow any participant to join for some interactions but not others. A participant also does not appear to have any input into future changes.

PA-2: Name a standard API along with having that API be fairly strictly defined. As the currently recommended APIs have a lot of flexibility and room for interpretation or different way to populate it especially for the same Resource in different Implementation Guides, it does not make for a standard implementation. It is very likely that we would have to construct a mapping for each different provider platform we connect to (not for each provider but to the EMR platform they use). This is unlike X12 or NCPDP transactions where we generally have one mapping and there are very little room for interpretation.

PA-3: Do not understand this enough to say that we would be able to use it. A question would be how to ensure that a digital identity is associated with the correct member we know. For example if we have 3 different John Browns, if a John Brown approaches us with a CLEAR login how do we  know to associate it correctly. Also if digital identities like this are used across multiple platforms and logins, are we not breaking with a cardinal rule on reuse of login/password - having all eggs in one basket - which could cause issues if that one login is hacked?

PA-4: It might make it easier to find the endpoint for any provider as long as the information is current and clearly delineates for which interactions each endpoint should be used if a provider has more than one endpoint. It will not make the establishment of the connection or getting credentials any easier, just the discovery of the endpoint alone.

PA-5a: I am not very interested in receiving bulk data from providers as this is a risk to us since the more data we as a payer receive then the more we data we are responsible for storing and delivering via the APIs.

PA-5b: None known at this time to make this any easier or less burdensome.

PA-7: Not sure that CMS can encourage payers to do this. Only if a provider were causing potential costs to us as a payer due to missing some regulatory or legal deadline would we consider doing this. Otherwise we would not want to risk alienating our providers for whom our relationship and keeping them in our network is very important.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
On behalf of the knowledgeable and innovative team of technologists here at Quadratic Digital, we appreciate the opportunity to provide comment on the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) request for information (RFI) regarding America’s Health Technology Ecosystem. As we look to the future, it is only through collaboration, courage, and conviction that we are able to forge decisive solutions resulting in a better tomorrow for all Americans. It is abundantly refreshing to see that CMS is seeking poignant, directed feedback from Patients, Payers, and Vendors alike, as this most assuredly will provide the most cohesive “big-picture” possible.

Quadratic Digital believes that CMS is uniquely positioned to effectuate very meaningful outcomes, not only for patients, but for all stakeholders in American healthcare infrastructure, through the implementation of meticulously crafted solutions leveraging a wide range of novel technologies. As America’s guiding health agency, CMS has a long history of safeguarding and enabling the American people to have improved access to valuable healthcare and coverage, dating back to its origination as the Healthcare Financing Administration (HCFA). The advent of Value-Based care models and Alternative Payment models speaks volumes to the inextricable coupling of healthcare’s delivery and financial implications.

Quadratic Digital strongly believes that critical aspects for a comprehensive application of technology resulting in better outcomes for patients and attainable, affordable health coverage include improved interoperability between stakeholders, meticulous use of cloud computing capabilities, and targeted use of interpretive analytics leveraging machine learning. We have attached our responses to your most critical inquiries.

As trusted technology partners to CMS, and foremost, as Americans, the team at Quadratic Digital recognizes a civic duty to aid in accomplishing these goals for our fellow Americans and want to thank CMS for the diligent dedication to this mission. As you well know, America’s Health Ecosystem is vastly complex, with a wide array of stakeholders and operations in play; each with a crucial role to health outcomes for the American people. Together, in unity, I am confident that these outcomes can be improved to fortify the American Health System through data-driven decisions and observation of outcomes. I hope you find our insights to be beneficial as the agency plans its roadmap to success.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
I do NOT support any digital id or digital health records by the government. If I want to access my or loved ones health records, I go to my/their health care provider. Nothing is ever safe and I do not believe you could keep this system safe. More is not better. Under NO circumstances should this technology be implemented.

1. There should be absolutely no digital ID requirement for any human being to access healthcare in America, ever.

2. No one should be forced to provide any biometric data to access healthcare in America, ever.

3. Everyone should have "the right to be forgotten," meaning if AI or other technological tools are being used to gather data on a patient it should be up to the individual if that data is stored or deleted.

4. Under no circumstances should any wearable technology ever be mandated on any human for any healthcare purpose. Informed consent must always be the standard.

I will never support this and this will not MAKE AMERICA HEALTHY AGAIN.

Health Gorilla, a designated QHIN under TEFCA, appreciates the opportunity to submit comments in response to CMS’s Request for Information (CMS–0042–NC) regarding the health technology ecosystem. As a leading national interoperability platform, Health Gorilla enables secure, real-time access to structured, AI-ready health data across a broad ecosystem of EHR vendors, value-based care organizations, and digital health innovators.

Our attached response reflects Health Gorilla’s deep experience in the interoperability space and offers detailed recommendations on advancing patient and provider access, strengthening digital identity frameworks, enhancing TEFCA-based workflows, and supporting care through modern, standards-based infrastructure.

We thank CMS for its continued leadership and look forward to ongoing collaboration to support a more connected, transparent, and equitable healthcare system.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
PA-1) What policy or technical limitations do you see in TEFCA? What changes would you suggest to address those limitations? To what degree do you expect these limitations to hinder participation in TEFCA?
•	CMS should require payer access to QHIN via required API to access and exchange provider EHR data

PA-2) How can CMS encourage payers to accelerate use of APIs for patients
•	CMS should focus on more promotion of patient access API in CMS Medicare educational and marketing materials

PA-3) Can CMS encourage plans to accept digital identity credentials, such as: CLEAR (airports), ID.me, Login.gov?
•	Plans having to use external authentication credentials complicates process.
•	The main issue is lack of a common enrollee identifier. Even if some systems login credential could be used, apps and plan need a common identifier to relate individual logging in with enrollee in plan system.

PA-4) Value of national provider directory of FHIR endpoints
•	National provider endpoint directory is very useful for plans to use implementing 2027 Prior Auth and Provider Access API mandate, and reduce threat from exchanging data with fraudulent actors

PA-5) Ways the plans can help simplify clinical quality data responsibilities of providers
a. How interested are plans and providers in EHR technology to enable bulk extraction of clinical quality from EHRs to payers for them to do calculations? 
•	Requiring an HL7 standard format, validated by NCQA, that includes bulk data extraction of quality data to plans from EHRs through national data aggregators would simplify data exchanges for both parties and alleviate proprietary plan format variations that providers otherwise encounter

b. In what ways can the interoperability and quality reporting responsibilities of providers to CMS and other payers be consolidated so investments can be dually purposed?  Technologies that support both informed clinical care and reporting?
•	Consolidated Clinical Document Architecture (CCDA) is a standard for health data exchange, which a patient health encounter can be represented by a single electronic document. Adoption and dual required use of this standard format for both clinical quality reporting and clinical record keeping by providers and plans would simplify data sharing and decrease migration to meet varied proprietary formats.  

TD-1) Steps CMS can take to stimulate developer interest to build digital health products for Medicare enrollees
d.	What APIs should CMS & ASTP/ONC consider to unleash innovation to support patients & providers.
•	Require QHINs to allow payer access for data exchange via APIs between providers and plans

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
The US government should adopt formal ontologies.

List of benefits:
1.	Semantic Alignment Across Agencies Without Schema Lock-in
•	Formal ontologies enable CMS, SSA, VA, and others to define domain-specific concepts independently while aligning on shared upper-level concepts (e.g., Person, Benefit, Encounter).
•	This supports semantic interoperability despite differing database schemas—key for TEFCA and whole-of-government data integration.
2.	Leverages NLM’s Trusted Expertise in Health Data Semantics
•	NLM’s stewardship of SNOMED CT, RxNorm, LOINC, and UMLS positions it well to coordinate federal formal ontology development.
•	A centralized branch (e.g., Health Data Standards Branch) could manage publishing, harmonization, version control, and API services.
3.	Supports Responsible AI and Large Language Model (LLM) Adoption
•	Ontologies provide AI systems with a ground-truth semantic layer that anchors predictions and conversational responses in well-defined concepts.
•	This enhances explainability, traceability, and trust, especially for CMS’s beneficiary-facing AI tools and decision support.
4.	Enables Smarter Interoperability in TEFCA and FHIR Exchange
•	Ontologies can support granular consent management (e.g., mental health, substance use disorder), data segmentation, and context-driven routing decisions.
•	FHIR natively supports integration with ontologies through CodeSystem, ValueSet, and StructureDefinition resources.
5.	Improves Program Evaluation and Policy Simulation
•	CMS can model value-based care, ACO attribution, social risk factors, and eligibility criteria using ontologies, enabling:
o	Policy simulation
o	AI-powered quality forecasting
o	Alignment of plain-language notices via natural language processing
6.	Enables Downstream Graph-Based Reasoning (Optional Future Phase)
•	After establishing agency ontologies, CMS can adopt graph databases and semantic reasoners (e.g., Neo4j, Stardog, SPARQL engines) for real-time inference.
•	This phased approach respects existing infrastructure and promotes standards-first adoption without immediate platform overhaul.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Azuba Corporation – Public Comment Summary for CMS-0042-NC

Azuba Corporation respectfully submits this public comment in response to CMS-0042-NC, offering a production-ready platform that delivers multilingual communications, FHIR-driven interoperability, and real-time access to longitudinal clinical records. We support CMS’s bold vision to eliminate legacy burdens, expand digital access, and empower beneficiaries with co-equal participation in healthcare delivery and decision-making.

Azuba’s Health Communication Platform builds upon our enterprise-grade CCM solution, in use since 1986. It supports over 220 APIs and connects to 500+ EHRs, enabling real-time, standards-based access to clinical data for more than 100M CMS-covered lives and 260M+ individuals overall—including members across UnitedHealthcare, Elevance, and HCSC. Our workflows are multilingual (86 languages), compliant, and scalable, supporting tens of thousands of concurrent use cases and billions of transactions per year.

We propose the following CMS RFI-aligned recommendations:

PC-2, PC-9: Expand Blue Button 2.0 to support real-time FHIR access to clinical records, claims, ADT feeds, device data, and language metadata. Include endpoints for structured problem lists, immunizations, genomics, care plans, and prescription fills.

PC-14: Incentivize federated digital identity adoption via ID.me, Login.gov, etc., and support credential-based intake workflows. CMS should fund MA plan adoption and launch a revocable identity-linked app authorization portal.

TD-5: Create a CMS-hosted FHIR endpoint directory indexed by NPI with metadata: endpoint URL, supported FHIR version, TEFCA/QHIN participation, credentialing level (IAL2/AAL2), and access type (patient/provider/payer).

TD-8: Redefine certification to emphasize API maturity, longitudinal data completeness, and workflows for gap closure, ADT alerting, language capture, and SDOH tagging.

PR-8: Support FHIR bulk data export from EHRs for payer and APM performance reporting. Azuba processes bulk exports with deduplication, gap closure metrics, and submission-ready formats for HEDIS, MIPS, and Stars.

VB-3: Provide HIT infrastructure to APMs with configurable alerts, smart templates, attribution views, and member-driven engagement—extending support to caregivers and underserved communities.

Additionally, Azuba urges CMS to pilot a new model in which claims submission is replaced with real-time clinical FHIR APIs, enabling point-of-care adjudication validated against CMS coverage criteria. Our infrastructure supports this model today.

To demonstrate our alignment and readiness, Azuba has prepared seven (7) live use cases mapped to CMS RFI codes. These scenarios reflect real workflows in production and can be demonstrated virtually or in person:

Use Case 1: Care Manager Jane & Patient Irene
Payer/Provider Portal: One-click record retrieval across 500+ EHR systems touching 90%+ U.S. patients.
RFI Codes: PC-2, PC-10, VB-3

Use Case 2: Care Manager Jane & Patient Megan
ER Alerts: Real-time ADT-based notification with immediate record access.
RFI Codes: PC-9, VB-3, TD-8

Use Case 3: Claims Manager Eric & Patient Jerry
Direct Clinical Data for Adjudication: External record retrieval reduces claims cycle time.
RFI Codes: PR-8, TD-5, TD-8

Use Case 4: Member Megan & Daughter Carly
Smartphone Access: Credential-secured, caregiver-enabled data control.
RFI Codes: PC-1, PC-14, VB-3

Use Case 5: Care Manager Jane & Patient Irene (Mobile)
Emergency Mobile Access: Remote access to longitudinal records on-demand.
RFI Codes: PC-2, PC-10, VB-3

Use Case 6: Support Agent Dave & Patient John
24/7 Hotline Access: Agent portal delivers real-time access during after-hours needs.
RFI Codes: PC-10, VB-3, PR-8

Use Case 7: Support Agent Dave & Patient Megan
Workflow Automation: Optimized response time and service coordination.
RFI Codes: PC-1, TD-8, VB-3

Azuba's proven platform and readiness to execute place us in a strong position to partner with CMS on pilots that reduce administrative burden, eliminate fraud vectors, improve equity, and empower individuals.

Since 2010, Azuba executives have contributed to national health IT strategy via Blue Button, the Sequoia Project, Da Vinci, and the CARIN Alliance. We are deeply aligned with TEFCA and support CMS’s “good–better–best” glide path toward API-first, digitally verified, real-time data exchange. We invite CMS to leverage our deployed infrastructure in advancing national interoperability and health equity.

We welcome the opportunity to demonstrate these workflows to CMS.

Contact:
David Corso
EVP & Chief Revenue Officer

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
We believe CMS should encourage the use of technology that helps providers deliver‬ higher-quality, lower-burden care that:‬
- Equips health care providers with better information about their patients to improve outcomes &‬ reduce burden on doctors‬
- Ensures every diagnosis has supporting evidence so that we know it is accurate, helping to‬ eliminate fraud & waste‬
- Catches diseases early to foster more preventative care instead of the current sick-care paradigm‬. This can be achieved by incentivizing health systems to adopt AI technologies that review 100% of‬‭ patient data and surface evidence-backed diagnoses. CMS should prioritize technology that fits‬ seamlessly into the provider workflow. Creating CPT codes or AI pathways for NTAP would support‬ these efforts

Please see the attached file for our full response.

Thank you very much for taking these into consideration.
